title: Choking hazards
description: Baby's pincer grasp is developing, meaning they can pick up very small objects. Keep coins, buttons, batteries, small toys, and any item smaller than a toilet paper roll out of reach.
action: Do a daily floor sweep for small objects. Cut food into small pieces (no larger than 1/2 inch). Avoid round, hard foods like whole grapes, hot dogs, and popcorn.
sourceQuote: Children under age 3 are at the highest risk of choking. Any object small enough to fit through a toilet paper roll is a potential choking hazard.

title: Pulling up hazards
description: Baby is starting to pull up on furniture. Unsecured furniture, tablecloths, and items on table edges become dangerous as baby can pull things down on themselves.
action: Secure heavy furniture to walls with anti-tip anchors. Remove tablecloths. Keep hot drinks and heavy objects away from table edges.
sourceQuote: Tip-over incidents involving furniture and TVs send thousands of children to the emergency room each year. Anchoring furniture to the wall is the most effective prevention.

title: Stranger anxiety is normal
description: Baby may become very upset around unfamiliar people, even relatives they haven't seen recently. This is a healthy developmental sign, not a behavioral problem.
action: Give baby time to warm up to new people. Don't force interactions. Let baby observe from your arms before approaching others.
sourceQuote: Stranger anxiety is a sign that your baby understands the difference between familiar and unfamiliar people, reflecting healthy emotional and social development.

title: Stair safety
description: Mobile babies can reach stairs quickly and are at high risk for falls. They can climb up but cannot safely come back down.
action: Install safety gates at the top and bottom of all staircases. Teach baby to go down stairs safely by backing down feet first.
sourceQuote: Falls are the leading cause of injury for young children. Safety gates at the top and bottom of stairs are essential once babies begin to crawl and cruise.

title: Electrical outlet danger
description: Crawling babies are at the perfect height to explore electrical outlets. They may try to stick fingers or objects into them.
action: Cover all accessible electrical outlets with outlet covers or plates. Keep cords out of reach and secured.
sourceQuote: Electrical outlets should be covered with safety caps or tamper-resistant receptacles to prevent children from inserting objects that could cause shock or burns.

title: Separation anxiety peak
description: Separation anxiety typically peaks between 10-18 months. Baby may become extremely clingy and distressed when you leave the room.
action: Create consistent goodbye rituals. Keep separations brief at first and gradually extend. Always say goodbye rather than sneaking away.
sourceQuote: Separation anxiety shows that your child has formed a strong, healthy attachment. Consistent and reassuring goodbye routines help children learn that you always come back.

title: Cabinet and drawer safety
description: Baby can now open cabinets and drawers, accessing cleaning supplies, medications, sharp objects, and other hazards.
action: Install child-proof locks on all cabinets containing hazardous items. Move cleaning supplies and medications to high shelves. Lock the medicine cabinet.
sourceQuote: Household cleaning products and medications should be stored in locked cabinets out of children's reach. Child-resistant packaging is not child-proof.

title: Walking readiness varies
description: Some babies walk at 9 months, others at 15+ months. Both are normal. Don't pressure baby to walk before they're ready.
action: Avoid walkers (they can delay walking and cause injuries). Let baby cruise, stand, and step at their own pace. Consult your pediatrician if baby isn't walking by 18 months.
sourceQuote: The AAP advises against infant walkers, as they can cause injuries and may delay motor development. Children develop walking skills on their own timeline.

title: Bath safety
description: Babies can drown in as little as 1 inch of water. They can also slip and hit their head on hard tub surfaces.
action: Never leave baby alone in the bath, even for a moment. Use a non-slip mat. Keep water temperature below 100F (38C). Always test water before placing baby in.
sourceQuote: A child can drown in just one inch of water. Never leave a young child unattended in or near any body of water, including bathtubs, even for a moment.

title: Transitioning from bottle to cup
description: The AAP recommends weaning from bottles by 12-15 months. Prolonged bottle use can affect dental development and increase risk of tooth decay.
action: Start offering milk in a sippy cup or open cup. Gradually reduce bottle feedings, eliminating the bedtime bottle last.
sourceQuote: Pediatricians recommend weaning from the bottle by 12 to 15 months of age, as prolonged bottle use is associated with dental cavities and excess calorie intake.

title: Whole milk transition
description: At 12 months, baby can transition to whole cow's milk. However, too much milk can displace solid food intake and lead to iron deficiency.
action: Limit whole milk to 16-24 oz per day. Ensure baby is eating a variety of iron-rich foods. Continue offering water throughout the day.
sourceQuote: After 12 months, children can begin drinking whole cow's milk, but intake should be limited to 16-24 ounces per day to ensure adequate iron and nutrient intake from solid foods.

title: Head injuries from early walking
description: New walkers fall frequently and can hit their heads on hard surfaces, furniture corners, and sharp edges.
action: Pad sharp furniture corners. Keep floors clear of tripping hazards. Monitor closely but allow reasonable exploration. Know the signs of concussion.
sourceQuote: Falls are the most common cause of injury in children learning to walk. Padding sharp corners and clearing floors of obstacles can reduce the risk of head injuries.

title: Picky eating may begin
description: Many toddlers become more selective about food around this age. Food jags (wanting only one food) and refusing previously accepted foods are common.
action: Continue offering a variety of foods without pressure. It can take 10-15 exposures before a child accepts a new food. Don't make separate meals.
sourceQuote: Picky eating is a normal part of toddler development as children assert independence. Repeated, pressure-free exposure to new foods is the best approach to expanding their diet.

title: Climbing furniture risks
description: Toddlers who can walk start climbing on everything. Bookshelves, dressers, and TVs are serious tip-over hazards.
action: Anchor all tall furniture and TVs to the wall. Remove items that encourage climbing near windows or on high surfaces.
sourceQuote: A child dies every two weeks from furniture or TV tip-overs. The CPSC urges all families to anchor furniture and TVs to the wall to prevent these preventable tragedies.

title: Window and balcony safety
description: Mobile toddlers can climb to windows and are at risk for falls. Window screens are not strong enough to prevent falls.
action: Install window guards or stops that prevent windows from opening more than 4 inches. Keep furniture away from windows. Supervise on balconies.
sourceQuote: Window screens are designed to keep insects out, not to prevent children from falling. Install window guards or stops to limit openings to 4 inches or less.

title: Language development monitoring
description: By 14 months, baby should be using a few words and understanding simple commands. Significant delays may warrant evaluation.
action: Talk and read to baby frequently. If baby uses no words and doesn't seem to understand simple phrases, discuss with your pediatrician at the next visit.
sourceQuote: Monitoring your child's developmental milestones helps catch concerns early. If your child is not meeting communication milestones, early intervention can make a meaningful difference.

title: 15-month well-child visit
description: The 15-month checkup includes important vaccinations and developmental screening. Don't skip this appointment.
action: Schedule the 15-month well-child visit. Prepare a list of developmental concerns or questions. Bring your baby's health records.
sourceQuote: Well-child visits are essential for tracking growth, development, and administering recommended vaccinations on schedule to protect your child's health.

title: Tantrums may start
description: Toddlers understand more than they can express, leading to frustration. Early tantrums often appear around 15-18 months.
action: Stay calm during tantrums. Acknowledge feelings: 'I know you're frustrated.' Offer simple choices to give some control. Ensure safety during the tantrum.
sourceQuote: Tantrums are a normal part of development when toddlers' desire to do things outpaces their ability to communicate. Staying calm and validating feelings helps children learn to manage emotions.

title: Dental care
description: Baby should have their first dental visit by age 1 or within 6 months of the first tooth. Early dental care prevents future problems.
action: Schedule a dental visit if not done yet. Brush teeth twice daily with a rice-grain-sized amount of fluoride toothpaste. Avoid juice and sugary drinks.
sourceQuote: The AAP recommends a child's first dental visit by age 1 or within 6 months of the first tooth. Early preventive dental care reduces the risk of cavities and future dental problems.

title: Toddler-proofing the kitchen
description: Toddlers are increasingly mobile and curious. The kitchen contains hot surfaces, sharp objects, and chemicals within climbing reach.
action: Use stove knob covers and back burners. Turn pot handles inward. Store knives and chemicals up high. Keep toddler away from the stove when cooking.
sourceQuote: Burns from hot liquids and contact with stoves are among the most common kitchen injuries in young children. Using back burners and turning pot handles inward are simple, effective precautions.

title: Screen time limits
description: The AAP recommends avoiding screen time (except video chatting) for children under 18 months. Excessive screen time can affect language development.
action: Limit or avoid screen time. If using screens, watch together and talk about what you see. Prioritize interactive play, reading, and outdoor time.
sourceQuote: The AAP recommends avoiding digital media use, except video chatting, for children younger than 18 months, as interactive play better supports language and cognitive development.

title: Climbing out of crib
description: Some toddlers start climbing out of their crib around this age, creating a fall risk.
action: Lower the mattress to its lowest position. Remove bumpers, toys, and pillows that could be used as stepping stones. If climbing persists, consider transitioning to a toddler bed.
sourceQuote: Set the crib mattress to the lowest position as soon as your child can pull to stand. Remove any objects from the crib that could be used as a step for climbing out.

title: Throwing objects
description: Toddlers love to throw things as part of learning cause and effect. This can lead to broken items or injuries.
action: Provide safe throwing opportunities with soft balls. Redirect throwing of hard or dangerous objects. Say 'Balls are for throwing, blocks are not.'
sourceQuote: Throwing is how toddlers explore cause and effect and develop motor skills. Providing appropriate outlets for throwing helps channel this behavior constructively.

title: 18-month developmental screening
description: The AAP recommends autism screening at 18 months. This is a critical checkpoint for identifying developmental concerns early.
action: Attend the 18-month well-child visit. Complete any screening questionnaires your pediatrician provides. Discuss any concerns about social interaction, communication, or repetitive behaviors.
sourceQuote: The AAP recommends developmental screening at 9, 18, and 30 months, and autism-specific screening at 18 months. Early identification leads to earlier access to services that improve outcomes.

title: Biting and hitting
description: Toddlers may bite, hit, or push when frustrated, angry, or overwhelmed. This is common but needs consistent, calm guidance.
action: Stay calm. Say 'No biting. Biting hurts.' Comfort the other child first. Help toddler use words for feelings. Never bite back as punishment.
sourceQuote: Biting and hitting are common in toddlers who lack the language to express strong feelings. Responding calmly and consistently helps children gradually develop self-control.

title: Car seat safety check
description: Ensure your child is still rear-facing in their car seat. The AAP recommends rear-facing until at least age 2 or until they exceed the car seat's weight/height limit.
action: Keep car seat rear-facing. Check that the harness fits snugly. Verify the seat is installed correctly. Never use a car seat that has been in an accident.
sourceQuote: Children should ride in a rear-facing car seat as long as possible, until they reach the maximum height or weight allowed by the seat. Rear-facing provides the best protection for a child's head, neck, and spine.

title: Running into danger
description: Newly mobile runners may dash toward streets, parking lots, or other dangerous areas without awareness of danger.
action: Hold hands in parking lots and near streets. Teach 'stop' as a safety command. Practice listening to 'freeze' and 'wait.' Never let toddler walk unattended near traffic.
sourceQuote: Young children have no concept of traffic safety and may dart into the street without warning. Always hold a child's hand in or near roadways and parking areas.

title: Sleep regression
description: Many toddlers experience a sleep regression around 18-21 months, with resistance to bedtime, night wakings, or early morning waking.
action: Maintain a consistent bedtime routine. Keep the same sleep schedule. Be patient; most regressions pass in 2-6 weeks. Avoid introducing new sleep crutches.
sourceQuote: Sleep disruptions are common during periods of rapid development. Maintaining a consistent, calming bedtime routine helps toddlers settle back into healthy sleep patterns.

title: Water safety
description: Toddlers are attracted to water but have no awareness of drowning danger. Pools, bathtubs, buckets, and even toilets are hazards.
action: Never leave toddler unattended near any water. Empty buckets and wading pools after use. Install pool fences with self-closing gates. Keep toilet lids locked.
sourceQuote: Drowning is the leading cause of death for children ages 1 to 4. Constant adult supervision and barriers like pool fencing are the most effective ways to prevent drowning.

title: Defiance is developmental
description: Saying 'no' to everything and testing boundaries is a normal, healthy part of developing autonomy. It's not misbehavior.
action: Offer limited choices instead of yes/no questions. Pick your battles. Stay calm and consistent with important boundaries. Praise cooperation when it happens.
sourceQuote: Toddlers say 'no' as a way of asserting their growing sense of self. Offering limited choices gives them a healthy sense of control while keeping them safe.

title: Playground safety
description: Toddlers are climbing higher and trying new things on playground equipment. Falls from heights are a common source of injuries.
action: Stay within arm's reach on playground equipment. Choose age-appropriate equipment. Check that the ground surface is soft (mulch, rubber). Avoid equipment taller than 4 feet.
sourceQuote: Most playground injuries are caused by falls. Using age-appropriate equipment with proper safety surfacing underneath significantly reduces the risk of serious injury.

title: Tooth brushing battles
description: Many toddlers resist tooth brushing. However, dental hygiene is critical, especially as more teeth come in.
action: Make brushing fun with songs or games. Let toddler hold their own brush while you do the actual brushing. Use a timer or fun app. Brush twice daily.
sourceQuote: Parents should brush their child's teeth twice daily using a smear of fluoride toothpaste. Good oral hygiene habits established early help prevent cavities throughout childhood.

title: Emotional outbursts increasing
description: Peak tantrum age is typically 18-24 months. Toddler has big emotions and limited ability to regulate or communicate them.
action: Validate emotions: 'You're really angry right now.' Stay nearby but calm. Don't give in to demands made during tantrums. Teach simple emotion words.
sourceQuote: Toddlers experience intense emotions but are still developing the brain pathways needed for self-regulation. Naming feelings and staying calm teaches them to manage emotions over time.

title: Poisoning prevention
description: Curious toddlers can access cleaning products, medications, and plants. Poisoning is a leading cause of injury for children under 5.
action: Store all medications and cleaning products locked and out of reach. Keep Poison Control number saved: 1-800-222-1222. Know which houseplants are toxic.
sourceQuote: Over 2 million poisoning cases involving children under 6 are reported each year. Store all household chemicals and medicines in locked cabinets out of children's sight and reach.

title: Potty training readiness
description: Some toddlers show signs of potty readiness around 2 years old. Starting too early can create frustration for both parent and child.
action: Look for readiness signs: staying dry for 2+ hours, interest in the toilet, telling you about wet/dirty diapers. Don't force it; follow child's lead.
sourceQuote: Most children show signs of readiness for toilet training between 18 and 24 months. Following the child's cues rather than a strict timeline leads to more successful outcomes.

title: Rope and cord hazards
description: Toddlers may play with cords from blinds, curtains, or charging cables, creating strangulation risk.
action: Replace corded blinds with cordless ones. Keep all cords and strings out of reach. Tie up curtain cords and charging cables. Remove necklaces and long strings from toys.
sourceQuote: Window blind cords are among the top hidden hazards in homes. The CPSC recommends using only cordless window coverings in homes with young children to prevent strangulation.

title: 2-year well-child visit
description: The 2-year checkup includes a second autism screening, developmental assessment, and health review. This is an important milestone visit.
action: Schedule the 2-year well-child visit. Note developmental milestones reached and any concerns. Bring questions about behavior, sleep, eating, and development.
sourceQuote: The CDC recommends developmental screening at the 2-year well-child visit, including a second autism-specific screening. Tracking milestones helps identify concerns when early intervention is most effective.

title: Turning car seat forward-facing
description: At age 2, many parents consider turning the car seat forward-facing. However, rear-facing is still safer as long as the child meets weight/height limits.
action: Keep rear-facing as long as possible within the car seat's limits. When switching to forward-facing, ensure the harness is properly positioned at or above shoulders.
sourceQuote: The AAP recommends keeping children rear-facing as long as possible, up to the maximum height and weight limits of the car seat. Rear-facing seats provide superior crash protection.

title: Aggressive behavior with peers
description: Toddlers at this age may push, grab, or hit other children. They're still learning social skills and impulse control.
action: Supervise play closely. Intervene calmly and quickly. Model gentle behavior. Use simple words: 'Gentle hands.' Remove child briefly if behavior continues.
sourceQuote: Aggressive behavior in toddlers reflects their still-developing impulse control and limited social skills. Calm, consistent guidance helps children gradually learn to interact with peers.

title: Toddler bed transition safety
description: If transitioning from crib to toddler bed, the entire room must be child-proofed since toddler can roam freely.
action: Secure furniture to walls. Cover outlets. Remove choking hazards. Install a gate at the bedroom door or top of stairs. Use a bed rail to prevent rolling out.
sourceQuote: When transitioning to a toddler bed, the entire room becomes the child's sleep environment. Anchor furniture, cover outlets, and use safety gates to keep the space safe.

title: Sun safety
description: Toddlers spending more time outdoors need sun protection. Their skin is more sensitive to UV damage than adults.
action: Apply SPF 30+ sunscreen 15 minutes before going outside. Reapply every 2 hours. Use hats and UV-protective clothing. Seek shade during peak hours (10am-2pm).
sourceQuote: Children's skin is more vulnerable to sun damage than adults'. The AAP recommends broad-spectrum SPF 30+ sunscreen, protective clothing, and seeking shade during peak UV hours.

title: Nightmares may begin
description: Some toddlers start having nightmares around this age. They may wake up crying and be scared of the dark or monsters.
action: Comfort and reassure your child. Use a nightlight if darkness is scary. Avoid scary content before bed. Maintain a calming bedtime routine.
sourceQuote: Nightmares can begin as a child's imagination develops. Comforting your child and maintaining a predictable bedtime routine helps them feel safe and secure at night.

title: Driveway and garage safety
description: Toddlers are hard to see behind vehicles. Driveway backover accidents are a serious risk.
action: Always know where your toddler is before moving a vehicle. Walk around the car before backing up. Hold toddler's hand in driveways. Keep garage doors closed.
sourceQuote: Young children are especially at risk for backover injuries because they are small and difficult to see behind vehicles. Always check behind your car before moving it.

title: Dog and pet safety
description: Toddlers may not understand gentle touch with pets. Even family pets can bite when startled, hurt, or resource-guarding.
action: Never leave toddler unsupervised with any pet. Teach gentle petting. Keep toddler away from pets that are eating. Learn to read pet stress signals.
sourceQuote: Most dog bites to children come from a familiar dog, often the family pet. Children should always be supervised around animals and taught to interact gently.

title: Refusing vegetables is normal
description: Many toddlers go through a phase of rejecting vegetables. This is biologically normal as toddlers become more cautious of bitter tastes.
action: Keep offering vegetables without pressure. Serve them alongside accepted foods. Try different preparations (roasted, pureed, raw with dip). Model eating vegetables yourself.
sourceQuote: Toddlers are naturally cautious about new and bitter-tasting foods as a protective instinct. Research shows that repeated, no-pressure exposure is the most effective way to broaden food acceptance.

title: Scissor safety
description: If introducing child-safe scissors, toddlers may try to cut things that aren't paper: hair, clothing, or fingers.
action: Only allow scissors during supervised activities. Use child-safe scissors with rounded tips. Teach that scissors are only for paper. Store out of reach when not in use.
sourceQuote: When introducing scissors, always supervise closely and use child-safe scissors with blunt tips. Teaching proper use early helps build fine motor skills while preventing injuries.

title: Stuttering may appear
description: It's common for toddlers to stutter or repeat words as their language develops rapidly. Most developmental stuttering resolves on its own.
action: Don't draw attention to the stuttering. Maintain eye contact and wait patiently. Don't finish their sentences. Speak slowly yourself. If it persists past 6 months, consult a speech-language pathologist.
sourceQuote: Developmental stuttering is common between ages 2 and 5 as children's language skills are rapidly expanding. Most children outgrow it naturally without intervention.

title: Running and falling risks
description: Toddlers are running faster but still developing coordination. Falls on hard surfaces, stairs, and uneven ground are common.
action: Ensure outdoor play areas have soft surfaces. Keep pathways clear of tripping hazards. Have toddler wear supportive shoes with non-slip soles.
sourceQuote: Unintentional falls are the leading cause of non-fatal injuries in young children. Safe footwear and clear play areas help reduce the risk as toddlers develop coordination.

title: Imaginary fears
description: As imagination develops, toddlers may develop fears of the dark, monsters, loud noises, or unfamiliar situations.
action: Take fears seriously even if they seem irrational. Use a nightlight. Read books about overcoming fears. Avoid forcing child into scary situations. Offer comfort and reassurance.
sourceQuote: Emerging fears are a sign of a growing imagination and developing cognitive abilities. Taking a child's fears seriously and offering comfort helps build their sense of security.

title: 30-month developmental check
description: Some pediatricians schedule a 30-month visit. Even without a formal visit, this is a good time to check developmental milestones.
action: Review CDC developmental milestones for 30 months. Contact your pediatrician if toddler doesn't use 2-word phrases, doesn't know what to do with familiar objects, or doesn't copy actions and words.
sourceQuote: Developmental monitoring at 30 months helps identify children who may benefit from early intervention services. Tracking milestones at home between visits is an important part of your child's care.

title: Button battery danger
description: Button batteries are found in many household items (remotes, toys, watches). If swallowed, they can cause severe internal burns within 2 hours.
action: Secure all battery compartments with tape or screws. Keep loose batteries locked away. If swallowing is suspected, go to the ER immediately. Do not induce vomiting.
sourceQuote: Button batteries can cause serious injury or death if swallowed. A swallowed battery can burn through a child's esophagus in as little as two hours. Seek emergency care immediately.

title: Potty training pressure
description: If potty training is underway, avoid putting too much pressure on the child. Stress and pressure can lead to resistance and setbacks.
action: Celebrate successes without over-praising. Don't punish accidents. Be patient with regression. Avoid asking 'Do you need to go potty?' constantly.
sourceQuote: Toilet learning works best when children feel in control of the process. Pressure and punishment can create anxiety and lead to resistance, prolonging the process.

title: Medication safety
description: Toddlers can now open child-resistant (not child-proof) containers. Medication poisoning remains a top risk for this age group.
action: Store all medications locked and out of reach. Never call medicine 'candy.' Dispose of unused medications safely. Program Poison Control (1-800-222-1222) into your phone.
sourceQuote: Child-resistant packaging is not child-proof. More than 60,000 children are seen in emergency rooms each year due to unsupervised access to medicines. Always store medications locked and out of reach.

title: New sibling jealousy
description: If a new sibling arrives around this time, toddlers may regress in behavior (wanting a bottle, having accidents after being potty trained) or act out.
action: Give toddler special one-on-one time daily. Let them 'help' with the baby. Avoid major changes (new bed, potty training) right around the birth. Be patient with regression.
sourceQuote: Regression and jealousy when a new sibling arrives are normal reactions to a big life change. One-on-one time and involvement in baby care help toddlers adjust.

title: Furniture climbing escalation
description: Toddlers become more capable climbers. Kitchen counters, bathroom sinks, and high shelves become accessible, putting them near sharp objects, medicines, and hot items.
action: Remove step stools and chairs that enable climbing to dangerous areas. Keep knives, scissors, and hazardous items in locked or high cabinets. Install stove guards.
sourceQuote: As children grow more skilled at climbing, reassess your home for new hazards they can reach. Move dangerous items higher and remove furniture that serves as stepping stones.

title: Preschool readiness
description: If considering preschool, many programs start accepting children at age 3. Separation anxiety may resurface when starting a new environment.
action: Visit potential preschools together. Start with short trial visits. Read books about school. Create a consistent drop-off routine. Give it 2-4 weeks for adjustment.
sourceQuote: Transitions to new settings can be challenging for young children. Gradual introductions, consistent routines, and reading about the experience beforehand help ease the adjustment.

title: Frequent illness exposure
description: If in daycare or starting preschool, toddlers may get sick frequently (6-8 colds per year is normal). Their immune system is still developing.
action: Teach hand washing. Keep child home when running a fever. Ensure vaccinations are up to date. Consult your doctor about concerning symptoms, not just frequency of colds.
sourceQuote: It is normal for young children in group settings to get 6 to 8 colds per year. Frequent handwashing and staying current on vaccinations are the best ways to reduce illness.

title: Wandering and elopement
description: Toddlers who can open doors may wander outside unsupervised. This is extremely dangerous near roads, pools, or other hazards.
action: Install child-proof door handle covers or high deadbolts. Consider door alarms. Teach your address and phone number. Ensure yard is fenced. Always supervise outdoor play.
sourceQuote: Children who can reach and open doors can wander into dangerous situations quickly. Door locks, alarms, and fenced yards provide critical layers of protection.

title: Speech clarity expectations
description: By this age, strangers should understand about 75% of what your child says. If speech is very unclear, it may be worth evaluating.
action: If strangers can't understand most of what your child says, or if child is very frustrated trying to communicate, ask your pediatrician about a speech evaluation.
sourceQuote: By age 3, most of what a child says should be understandable to people outside the family. If speech is very difficult to understand, a speech-language evaluation may be helpful.

title: Preparing for the 3-year visit
description: The 3-year well-child visit includes a comprehensive developmental assessment, vision and hearing screening, and vaccination review.
action: Schedule the 3-year checkup. Track developmental milestones. Prepare questions about behavior, sleep, diet, and social development.
sourceQuote: The 3-year well-child visit is a key checkpoint that includes vision and hearing screening, developmental assessment, and a review of your child's overall health and growth.

title: Playground injuries
description: As children become more confident, they attempt more challenging playground activities. Falls from monkey bars, slides, and climbing structures are common.
action: Supervise closely at playgrounds. Ensure equipment is age-appropriate. Check for proper safety surfacing under equipment. Teach children to wait their turn.
sourceQuote: More than 200,000 children are treated in emergency rooms for playground injuries each year. Active supervision and age-appropriate equipment are key to safe outdoor play.

title: 3-year developmental milestones review
description: By age 3, child should be speaking in 3+ word sentences, playing with other children, following 2-3 step instructions, and running well. Notable gaps may warrant evaluation.
action: Review CDC milestones for 3 years. Discuss any concerns with your pediatrician. Early intervention services are most effective when started early.
sourceQuote: Research shows that early identification and intervention for developmental delays lead to better outcomes. If your child is not meeting key milestones by age 3, talk to your pediatrician.

title: Booster seat transition
description: Children should remain in a forward-facing car seat with harness as long as possible (typically until age 4-5 or max weight). Don't rush to a booster seat.
action: Keep child in a harnessed forward-facing car seat. Don't switch to a booster seat yet. Verify your car seat's weight and height limits.
sourceQuote: Children should ride in a forward-facing car seat with a harness for as long as possible, until they reach the seat's maximum height or weight. A harnessed seat provides better crash protection than a booster.

title: Setting consistent boundaries
description: By age 3, children test boundaries constantly. Inconsistent rules cause confusion and can increase challenging behavior.
action: Agree on rules with all caregivers. Be consistent in enforcement. Use natural consequences when possible. Explain rules simply: 'We hold hands in the parking lot because cars can hurt us.'
sourceQuote: Consistent, clear boundaries help children feel safe and learn self-discipline. When all caregivers follow the same rules, children are less confused and more cooperative.
